did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: The Charleston S.C. Typographical Union 43 collection consists of correspondence with other local unions; printed material authored by the Charleston Typographical Union No. 43, the International Typographical Union, and the Virginia-Carolina Typographical Conference; and volumes, including minute books, an account book, printed books of laws, and a 1958 convention program. This collection also inludes subject files on such topics as arbitration, arbitration cases, contract negotiations, contracts, newspaper negotiations, resolutions, and secretary-treasurer of the International Typographical Union. These subject files sometimes include correspondence.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Charleston Typographical Union 43 (Charleston, S.C.) Records, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Charleston Typographical Union 43 (Charleston, S.C.) records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1985.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS, EAD, NCEAD guidelines, and local Style Guide.
Accession from 6-15-1985 is represented in this finding aid.
This finding aid is NCEAD compliant.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Charleston Typographical Union 43 was a trade-union for the printing industry.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The records of the Charleston Typographical Union Local 43 consist of correspondence with other locals; printed material authored by Local 43, the International Typographical Union, and the Virginia-Carolina Typographical Conference; and volumes relating to the union's activities, including minute books, an account book, printed books of laws, and a 1958 convention program. The collection also inludes subject files on such topics as arbitration, arbitration cases, contract negotiations, contracts, newspaper negotiations, resolutions, and secretary-treasurer of the International Typographical Union. These subject files sometimes include correspondence. There is also some oversize material housed separately. Note: collection consists of two components, only one of which is represented by a box list.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

archref.unittitle: Raleigh N.C. International Typographical Union Local 54 Records, 1921-1948
archref.repository: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

scopecontent.p: Originally part of the Labor Archives collection, the original set of records of the Charleston Typographical Union 43 include correspondence and reports, primarily of the various persons who served as secretary-treasurer of Local 43, discussing arbitration, a ten per cent assessment on earnings of union members to promote the 44-hour week, wages, strike benefits and contributions, conventions, membership, dues, and traveling cards; information and reports from the parent organization; account books recording fines and assessments, expenditures, and receipts; minute books; applications for membership and membership and pension rolls; and published materials. There is currently no box list for these records.
Series includes correspondence with other locals.
Includes yearbooks, conference bulletins, union pamphlets, and publications.
Series includes minute books, account books, convention programs, and other union bound volumes.

arrangement.p: Series organized alphabetically as in original arrangement.
